alkanes.definitionText: Alkanes are organic acyclic compounds that consist of hydrogen and carbon atoms, where all of the carbon–carbon bonds are single.
alkanes.definitionCredits: S.A. Litvinova and N.V. Mankevich, "Organic Chemistry via Tables"

alkenes.definitionText: Alkenes are organic compounds that consist of hydrogen and carbon atoms, where at least one carbon–carbon double bond is present.

alkynes.definitionText: Alkynes are organic compounds that consist of hydrogen and carbon atoms, where at least one carbon–carbon triple bond is present.

aldehydes_and_ketones.definitionText: Aldehydes and ketones are organic compounds that contain a carbonyl functional group, consisting of a carbon atom double-bonded to an oxygen atom.

alcohols.definitionText: Alcohols are organic compounds that contain a hydroxyl functional group (-OH) bonded to a carbon atom.

ethers.definitionText: Ethers are organic compounds that contain an ether functional group, consisting of two carbon atoms bonded to an oxygen atom.

carboxylic_acids.definitionText: Carboxylic acids are organic acids that contain a carboxyl functional group (-COOH), consisting of a carbon atom double-bonded to an oxygen atom and also bonded to a hydroxyl group.

esters.definitionText: Esters are organic compounds that contain an ester functional group, consisting of a carbon atom bonded to an oxygen atom and also bonded to an oxygen atom through a carbonyl group.

amines.definitionText: Amines are organic compounds that contain a nitrogen atom bonded to one or more carbon atoms.

aromatic_compounds.definitionText: Aromatic compounds are organic compounds that contain a planar ring of atoms with alternating double bonds known as an aromatic ring or an arene.
